elements.content: Three 1-D copper(II) coordination polymers have been obtained by using the nicotinato anion (NA-) as a bridge, and 2,2‘-bipyridine or dicyanamide (dca) as coligands:  Cu2(bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2·H2O 1, Cu2(Me2bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2 2, Cu3(NA)4(dca)2(H2O)8]·2H2O 3 (bipy = 2,2‘-bipyridine; Me2bipy = 4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine, dca = dicyanamide anion). The metal−ligand association in compounds 1 and 2 is very similar and generates tubelike coordination polymers, which are constructed from pairs of copper atoms connected through two carboxylato groups from two NA- ligands. Each pyridyl moiety from the NA- ligand coordinates at the apical position of the copper ions from another pair, resulting in chains running along the crystallographic c axis. The structure of 3 consists of infinite ladderlike chains:  the rungs are formed by trinuclear [Cu3] moieties, with the copper(II) ions connected through NA- bridges, the ladder sides being constructed from dca- bridging ligands. The cryomagnetic investigation of the three compounds reveals weak antiferromagnetic interactions mediated by the nicotinato ligand, 1:  J = −7.3 cm-1, 2: −15.3 cm-1, 3: −0.58 cm-1.
elements.clean_text: Three 1-D copper(II) coordination polymers have been obtained by using the nicotinato anion (NA-) as a bridge, and 2,2‘-bipyridine or dicyanamide (dca) as coligands:   Cu2(bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2⋅H2O 1,   Cu2(Me2bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2 2,   Cu3(NA)4(dca)2(H2O)8]⋅2H2O 3 (bipy = 2,2‘-bipyridine; Me2bipy = 4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine, dca = dicyanamide anion). The metal-ligand association in compounds 1 and 2 is very similar and generates tubelike coordination polymers, which are constructed from pairs of copper atoms connected through two carboxylato groups from two NA- ligands. Each pyridyl moiety from the NA- ligand coordinates at the apical position of the copper ions from another pair, resulting in chains running along the crystallographic c axis. The structure of 3 consists of infinite ladderlike chains: the rungs are formed by trinuclear [Cu3] moieties, with the copper(II) ions connected through NA- bridges, the ladder sides being constructed from dca- bridging ligands. The cryomagnetic investigation of the three compounds reveals weak antiferromagnetic interactions mediated by the nicotinato ligand, 1: J = -7.3 cm-1, 2: -15.3 cm-1, 3: -0.58 cm-1.

elements.content: Three new copper(II) coordination polymers have been obtained by using the nicotinato anion (NA-) as a bridge, and bipyridine or dicyanamide (dca-) as coligands:  Cu2(bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2·2H2O 1, Cu2(Me2bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2 2, Cu3(NA)4(dca)2(H2O)8]·2H2O. 3 (bipy = 2,2‘-bipyridine; Me2bipy = 4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine, dca = dicyanamide anion). Compounds 1 and 2 are tubelike coordination polymers, while the structure of 3 consists of a ladderlike chain.
elements.clean_text: Three new copper(II) coordination polymers have been obtained by using the nicotinato anion (NA-) as a bridge, and bipyridine or dicyanamide (dca-) as coligands:   Cu2(bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2⋅2H2O 1,   Cu2(Me2bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2 2,   Cu3(NA)4(dca)2(H2O)8]⋅2H2O. 3 (bipy = 2,2‘-bipyridine; Me2bipy = 4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine, dca = dicyanamide anion). Compounds 1 and 2 are tubelike coordination polymers, while the structure of 3 consists of a ladderlike chain.

elements.content: The nicotinate ion, NA-, is a quite interesting ligand:  first of all, its exodentate nature makes it a valuable tecton for designing high-dimensional coordination polymers. The nicotinato ligand combines the coordination ability of the pyridyl moiety with the various coordination modes of the carboxylato group. Moreover, its lower symmetry, in comparison with the isonicotinato ligand, fulfills a prerequisite in the attempt to obtain acentric coordination networks with interesting optical properties. Novel coordination polymers with various dimensionalities and solid-state architectures have been described. Most of these systems have been obtained by using solely the nicotinato ligand. Some other compounds have been obtained by using ancillary ligands:  azido, thiocyanato, diethylenetriamine. The stereochemical preference of the metallic ion as well as the conditions during crystallization (mild or hydrothermal synthesis, the presence of organic guest molecules) play a crucial role in the resulting solid-state architectures. For example, the reaction between zinc nitrate and nicotinic acid led, under hydrothermal conditions, to a 2-D coordination polymer, [Zn(NA)2], which crystallizes in a chiral space group (Fdd2), while the zinc ions are tetracoordinated. The reaction between solutions of zinc perchlorate and 3-cyanopyridine, also under hydrothermal conditions, led to a 2-D coordination polymer, having the same formula, [Zn(NA)2], but with six-coordinated zinc ions (the nicotinate ion results from the hydrolysis of 3-cyanopyridine). This compound crystallizes also in a chiral space group, P43212. On the other hand, the reaction between zinc nitrate and nicotinic acid, in methanol, at room temperature, and in the presence of organic guest molecules (naphthalene, nitrobenzene) affords completely different networks, including a three-dimensional one. The copper(II) derivative, [Cu(NA)2], exhibits a 3-D structures, with five-coordinated copper centers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The nicotinate ion, NA-, is a quite interesting ligand: first of all, its exodentate nature makes it a valuable tecton for designing high-dimensional coordination polymers. The nicotinato ligand combines the coordination ability of the pyridyl moiety with the various coordination modes of the carboxylato group. Moreover, its lower symmetry, in comparison with the isonicotinato ligand, fulfills a prerequisite in the attempt to obtain acentric coordination networks with interesting optical properties. Novel coordination polymers with various dimensionalities and solid-state architectures have been described. Most of these systems have been obtained by using solely the nicotinato ligand. Some other compounds have been obtained by using ancillary ligands: azido, thiocyanato, diethylenetriamine. The stereochemical preference of the metallic ion as well as the conditions during crystallization (mild or hydrothermal synthesis, the presence of organic guest molecules) play a crucial role in the resulting solid-state architectures. For example, the reaction between zinc nitrate and nicotinic acid led, under hydrothermal conditions, to a 2-D coordination polymer, [Zn(NA)2], which crystallizes in a chiral space group (Fdd2), while the zinc ions are tetracoordinated. The reaction between solutions of zinc perchlorate and 3-cyanopyridine, also under hydrothermal conditions, led to a 2-D coordination polymer, having the same formula, [Zn(NA)2], but with six-coordinated zinc ions (the nicotinate ion results from the hydrolysis of 3-cyanopyridine). This compound crystallizes also in a chiral space group, P43212. On the other hand, the reaction between zinc nitrate and nicotinic acid, in methanol, at room temperature, and in the presence of organic guest molecules (naphthalene, nitrobenzene) affords completely different networks, including a three-dimensional one. The copper(II) derivative, [Cu(NA)2], exhibits a 3-D structures, with five-coordinated copper centers.

elements.content: The nicotinic acid itself, acting as a ligand, can generate extended structures:  it coordinates with the nitrogen atom to the metal ion, the structure being further expanded on the base of the classical synthon: Here we report on three new 1-D coordination polymers, which have been constructed by using the nicotinato tecton and, as coligands, 2,2‘-bipyridine (bipy), 4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine (Me2bipy), or the dicyanamide ion (dca- = N(CN)2 -).
elements.clean_text: The nicotinic acid itself, acting as a ligand, can generate extended structures: it coordinates with the nitrogen atom to the metal ion, the structure being further expanded on the base of the classical synthon: Here we report on three new 1-D coordination polymers, which have been constructed by using the nicotinato tecton and, as coligands, 2,2‘-bipyridine (bipy), 4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine (Me2bipy), or the dicyanamide ion (dca- = N(CN)2 -).

<label></label>
<graphic xlink:href="cg-2004-09797m_0008.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Synthesis of Cu 2 (bipy) 2 (NA) 2 ](ClO 4 ) 2 · H 2 O (1) and Cu 2 (Me 2 bipy) 2 (NA) 2 ](ClO 4 ) 2 (2). Compounds 1 and 2 were obtained by following the same procedure:  10 mL of aqueous solution containing 0.2 mmol of nicotinic acid and 10 mL of ethanolic solution containing 0.2 mmol of 2,2‘-bipyridine for compound 1 (4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine for compound 2), were added over 0.2 mmol of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O dissolved in 10 mL water. The slow evaporation of the resulted mixtures leads to blue crystals of 1 and 2. IR data (KBr, cm-1):  1: 1610s, 1570m, 1472w, 1444m, 1413m, 1317w, 1089vs, 763m, 729w, 698w, 622m; 2:  1614vs, 1571m, 1410s, 1245w, 1088vs, 830m, 760m, 699w, 623m, 561w, 514w.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

 Synthesis of     Cu  2  (bipy)  2  (NA)  2  ](ClO  4  )  2  ⋅ H  2  O (1) and     Cu  2  (Me  2  bipy)  2  (NA)  2  ](ClO  4  )  2  (2). Compounds 1 and 2 were obtained by following the same procedure: 10 mL of aqueous solution containing 0.2 mmol of nicotinic acid and 10 mL of ethanolic solution containing 0.2 mmol of 2,2‘-bipyridine for compound 1 (4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine for compound 2), were added over 0.2 mmol of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 10 mL water. The slow evaporation of the resulted mixtures leads to blue crystals of 1 and 2. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 1: 1610s, 1570m, 1472w, 1444m, 1413m, 1317w, 1089vs, 763m, 729w, 698w, 622m; 2: 1614vs, 1571m, 1410s, 1245w, 1088vs, 830m, 760m, 699w, 623m, 561w, 514w.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu 3 (NA) 4 (dca) 2 (H 2 O) 8 ] · 2H 2 O (3). A 10 mL aqueous solution containing 0.1 mmol of nicotinic acid and 10 mL of aqueous solution containing 0.2 mmol of Na[N(CN)2] were added over 0.1 mmol of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O dissolved in 10 mL of water. The resulted blue solution was left to evaporate at room temperature. After few days blue crystals of 3 were obtained. IR data (KBr, cm-1):  3413m, 3231m, 2294m, 2242m, 2170vs, 1617s, 1565s, 1391vs, 1195w, 1161w, 1057w, 762m, 694m, 654w.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of [Cu  3  (NA)  4  (dca)  2  (H  2  O)  8  ] ⋅ 2H  2  O (3). A 10 mL aqueous solution containing 0.1 mmol of nicotinic acid and 10 mL of aqueous solution containing 0.2 mmol of Na[N(CN)2] were added over 0.1 mmol of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 10  mL of water. The resulted blue solution was left to evaporate at room temperature. After few days blue crystals of 3 were obtained. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3413m, 3231m, 2294m, 2242m, 2170vs, 1617s, 1565s, 1391vs, 1195w, 1161w, 1057w, 762m, 694m, 654w.

elements.content: X-ray Structure Determination. The crystals were measured on a Bruker AXS SMART diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation monochromator). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques based on F 2 . The non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Calculations were performed using SHELX-97 crystallographic software package. The crystallographic data and other pertinent information are collected in Table ). Some parts of the structure 3 (mainly the dicyanamido ion and H2O ligands) are disordered over two positions in the ratio 9:1. This disorder has been included in the calculations to improve the overall quality of the data (R1 for all data decreases from 0.073 to 0.049). The carboxylato groups of the terminal nicotinato ligands is also disordered over two positions in the crystal.
elements.clean_text: X-ray Structure Determination. The crystals were measured on a Bruker AXS SMART diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation monochromator). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques based on F  2  . The non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Calculations were performed using SHELX-97 crystallographic software package. The crystallographic data and other pertinent information are collected in Table ). Some parts of the structure 3 (mainly the dicyanamido ion and H2O ligands) are disordered over two positions in the ratio 9:1. This disorder has been included in the calculations to improve the overall quality of the data (R1 for all data decreases from 0.073 to 0.049). The carboxylato groups of the terminal nicotinato ligands is also disordered over two positions in the crystal.

Magnetic Data. The magnetic measurements were carried out with a Quantum Design MPMS-5S SQUID magnetometer.

Results and Discussion

Two Tubelike Coordination Polymers. The reaction between copper(II) perchlorate, nicotinic acid, and 2,2‘-bipyridine, or 4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine, leads to two coordination polymers, respectively:  Cu2(bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2·H2O 1, and Cu2(Me2bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2 2. Since the metal−ligand association for compounds 1 and 2 are the same, only the coordination polymer in 1 will be described. The nicotinato ligand bridges simultaneously three copper(II) ions. The carboxylato group exhibits its classical syn − syn bridging mode forming pairs of copper atoms connected through two carboxylato groups from two NA- ligands. These pairs are further interconnected through the NA- ligands, each of which being coordinated to the apical position of the copper ion from an adjacent pair (Figure ). This particular coordination function of the nicotinato ligand leads to a tubelike polymer running along the crystallographic c axis (Figure ). The tubes are constructed from the copper ions and the nicotinato ligand. The bipy molecules are oriented toward the exterior of the tubes. The stereochemistry of the copper(II) ions is square pyramidal. The basal plane is formed by two nitrogen atoms arising from the bipy ligand [Cu(1)−N(1) = 1.9807(18) and Cu(1)−N(2) = 1.9826(17) Å] and two oxygen atoms from the carboxylato bridges [Cu(1)−O(1) = 2.0034(14) and Cu(1)−O(2) = 1.9625(14) Å]. The apical position is occupied by a nitrogen atom from the pyridyl moiety [Cu(1)−N(3) = 2.1977(17) Å]. The percentage of trigonal distortion from square pyramidal geometry is described by the parameter τ, defined as [(θ − φ)/60]×100, where θ and φ are the angles between the donor atoms forming the plane in a square-pyramidal geometry. The values of the τ parameter for the coordination polyhedron of copper(II) in 1 is 33.4%. The distance between the copper ions connected by the carboxylato group is 3.244 Å (3.215 Å in the case of compound 2).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Data. The magnetic measurements were carried out with a Quantum Design MPMS-5S SQUID magnetometer. 

Results and Discussion

 Two Tubelike Coordination Polymers. The reaction between copper(II) perchlorate, nicotinic acid, and 2,2‘-bipyridine, or 4,4‘-dimethyl-2,2‘-bipyridine, leads to two coordination polymers, respectively:   Cu2(bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2⋅H2O 1, and   Cu2(Me2bipy)2(NA)2](ClO4)2 2. Since the metal-ligand association for compounds 1 and 2 are the same, only the coordination polymer in 1 will be described. The nicotinato ligand bridges simultaneously three copper(II) ions. The carboxylato group exhibits its classical syn - syn bridging mode forming pairs of copper atoms connected through two carboxylato groups from two NA- ligands. These pairs are further interconnected through the NA- ligands, each of which being coordinated to the apical position of the copper ion from an adjacent pair (Figure ). This particular coordination function of the nicotinato ligand leads to a tubelike polymer running along the crystallographic c axis (Figure ). The tubes are constructed from the copper ions and the nicotinato ligand. The bipy molecules are oriented toward the exterior of the tubes. The stereochemistry of the copper(II) ions is square pyramidal. The basal plane is formed by two nitrogen atoms arising from the bipy ligand [Cu(1)-N(1) = 1.9807(18) and Cu(1)-N(2) = 1.9826(17) Å] and two oxygen atoms from the carboxylato bridges [Cu(1)-O(1) = 2.0034(14) and Cu(1)-O(2) = 1.9625(14) Å]. The apical position is occupied by a nitrogen atom from the pyridyl moiety [Cu(1)-N(3) = 2.1977(17) Å]. The percentage of trigonal distortion from square pyramidal geometry is described by the parameter τ, defined as [(θ - φ)/60]×100, where θ and φ are the angles between the donor atoms forming the plane in a square-pyramidal geometry. The values of the τ parameter for the coordination polyhedron of copper(II) in 1 is 33.4%. The distance between the copper ions connected by the carboxylato group is 3.244 Å (3.215 Å in the case of compound 2).

elements.content: The structural motif {Cu2(μ-carboxylato-O,O‘)2}, in 1 and 2, has been encountered with several discrete, binuclear copper(II) complexes. It can be viewed as resulting from the classical dimeric copper(II) acetate, by replacing two out of the four carboxylato bridges by two bipy (or Me2bipy) molecules. These ligands sustain the dicopper moiety through π−π stacking interactions established between the aromatic rings:  3.35−3.60 Å for 1, and 3.30−3.65 Å for 2 (Figure ). It is interesting to note that the aromatic contacts are different for the two compounds:  in the case of complex 1, the bipy molecules are disposed face-to-face, while, due to the steric hindrance between the methyl groups in 2, the Me2bipy molecules stack slightly offset.
elements.clean_text: The structural motif {Cu2(μ-carboxylato-O,O‘)2}, in 1 and 2, has been encountered with several discrete, binuclear copper(II) complexes. It can be viewed as resulting from the classical dimeric copper(II) acetate,  by replacing two out of the four carboxylato bridges by two bipy (or Me2bipy) molecules. These ligands sustain the dicopper moiety through π-π stacking interactions established between the aromatic rings: 3.35-3.60 Å for 1, and 3.30-3.65 Å for 2 (Figure ). It is interesting to note that the aromatic contacts are different for the two compounds: in the case of complex 1, the bipy molecules are disposed face-to-face, while, due to the steric hindrance between the methyl groups in 2, the Me2bipy molecules stack slightly offset.

elements.content: Views of the dimeric moieties in compounds1 and 2, showing the stacking interactions between the bipy (a) and Me2bipy (b) ligands.
elements.clean_text: 3  Views of the dimeric moieties in compounds1 and 2, showing the stacking interactions between the bipy (a) and Me2bipy (b) ligands.

elements.content: We note also that compound 1 forms a monohydrate, while compound 2 does not. Each crystallization water molecule in crystal 1 is hydrogen bonded to the oxygen atoms from different perchlorate ions. The perchlorate ions occupy the same relative positions in the lattices of 1 and 2. The water molecule in crystal 1 resides on a position that is void space in crystal 2. Consequently, compound 2 has a lower calculated density than 1 (See Table ).
elements.clean_text: We note also that compound 1 forms a monohydrate, while compound 2 does not. Each crystallization water molecule in crystal 1 is hydrogen bonded to the oxygen atoms from different perchlorate ions. The perchlorate ions occupy the same relative positions in the lattices of 1 and 2. The water molecule in crystal 1 resides on a position that is void space in crystal 2. Consequently, compound 2 has a lower calculated density than 1 (See Table ).

elements.content: An Infinite Ladderlike Chain. The reaction between copper perchlorate, nicotinic acid, and sodium dicyanamide affords another coordination polymer, with two different bridges, the nicotinato and dicyanamido ions. The structure of 3 consists of infinite chains, running along the crystallographic b axis, built up by copper(II) ions interconnected through two types of bridges:  the nicotinato and the dicyanamido ligands (Figure ). Each chain can be viewed as a ladder, where the rungs are formed by a triad of copper(II) ions linked by two NA- bridges. The ladder sides are formed by dca- ligands connecting the terminal copper atoms from each triade (Figure ). Let us have a closer look at the stereochemistry of each copper ion. The central copper atom is located on a center of inversion. It is coordinated by four aqua ligands and two oxygen atoms arising from two trans-disposed carboxylato groups of the NA- bridges [Cu(2)−O(3) = 2.0007(16) Å]. The other Cu(2)−oxygen distances (aqua ligands) are 1.9830(15) and 2.3020(17) Å. Consequently, the stereochemistry ofCu(2) can be described as an elongated octahedron. The peripheral copper centers along with the dca and aqua ligands coordinated to these ions are disordered over two positions (the major occupied position is labeled with A). These copper ions are coordinated by two cis aqua ligands [Cu(1A)−O(1A) = 1.971(2) Å; Cu(1A)−O(2A) = 2.303(2) Å], two nitrogen atoms arising from the pyridyl group of the trans NA- ligands [one from bridging nicotinato ion, Cu(1A)−N(1) = 2.017(2) Å, and one from the terminal nicotinato ion, Cu(1A)−N(2) = 2.029(2) Å], and by two nitrile nitrogens from the cis dca ligands [Cu(1A)−N(4A) = 1.977(2) Å; Cu(1A)−N(5A) = 2.623(3) Å]. The distance between the copper ions within a triad is 7.176(4) Å. Selected bond distances for the three compounds are collected in Tables and . Compound 3 is isostructural with a cobalt(II) complex reported by Batten et al. The main difference between the two structures consists of the strongly distorted octahedral stereochemistry of the copper ions, in comparison with the cobalt ones. This difference is due to the intervening Jahn−Teller effect in the case of copper(II). For the cobalt derivative, the orbital contribution to the magnetic moment does not allow the calculation of the value of the exchange interaction mediated by the nicotinato ligand, while this is possible for compound 3, since copper(II) has an orbitally nondegenerated ground state (see below).

The reaction between copper perchlorate, nicotinic acid, and sodium dicyanamide affords another coordination polymer, with two different bridges, the nicotinato and dicyanamido ions. The structure of 3 consists of infinite chains, running along the crystallographic b axis, built up by copper(II) ions interconnected through two types of bridges: the nicotinato and the dicyanamido ligands (Figure ). Each chain can be viewed as a ladder, where the rungs are formed by a triad of copper(II) ions linked by two NA- bridges. The ladder sides are formed by dca- ligands connecting the terminal copper atoms from each triade (Figure ). Let us have a closer look at the stereochemistry of each copper ion. The central copper atom is located on a center of inversion. It is coordinated by four aqua ligands and two oxygen atoms arising from two trans-disposed carboxylato groups of the NA- bridges [Cu(2)-O(3) = 2.0007(16) Å]. The other Cu(2)-oxygen distances (aqua ligands) are 1.9830(15) and 2.3020(17) Å. Consequently, the stereochemistry ofCu(2) can be described as an elongated octahedron. The peripheral copper centers along with the dca and aqua ligands coordinated to these ions are disordered over two positions (the major occupied position is labeled with A). These copper ions are coordinated by two cis aqua ligands [Cu(1A)-O(1A) = 1.971(2) Å; Cu(1A)-O(2A) = 2.303(2) Å], two nitrogen atoms arising from the pyridyl group of the trans NA- ligands [one from bridging nicotinato ion, Cu(1A)-N(1) = 2.017(2) Å, and one from the terminal nicotinato ion, Cu(1A)-N(2) = 2.029(2) Å], and by two nitrile nitrogens from the cis dca ligands [Cu(1A)-N(4A) = 1.977(2) Å; Cu(1A)-N(5A) = 2.623(3) Å]. The distance between the copper ions within a triad is 7.176(4) Å. Selected bond distances for the three compounds are collected in Tables  and . Compound 3 is isostructural with a cobalt(II) complex reported by Batten et al. The main difference between the two structures consists of the strongly distorted octahedral stereochemistry of the copper ions, in comparison with the cobalt ones. This difference is due to the intervening Jahn-Teller effect in the case of copper(II). For the cobalt derivative, the orbital contribution to the magnetic moment does not allow the calculation of the value of the exchange interaction mediated by the nicotinato ligand, while this is possible for compound 3, since copper(II) has an orbitally nondegenerated ground state (see below).

Magnetic Properties. The temperature dependence of the χM T product for compounds 1, 2, and 3, in the temperature range 1.9−300 K, is shown in Figures −7. χM is the magnetic susceptibility for a dimeric unit in compounds 1 and 2, and for a copper triad in 3.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic Properties. The temperature dependence of the χM T product for compounds 1, 2, and 3, in the  temperature range 1.9-300 K, is shown in Figures -7. χM is the magnetic susceptibility for a dimeric unit in compounds 1 and 2, and for a copper triad in 3.

elements.content: Let us discuss first the magnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2. At room temperature, the values of the χM T product are 0.92 cm3 mol-1 K (1) and 0.80 cm3 mol-1 K (2), expected for two isolated spin doublets (Figures and ). These values remain constant upon cooling until ca. 50 K (for 1), and ca. 80 K (for 2). Below these temperatures, χM T decreases more and more to reach 0.055 (1), and 0.026 cm3 mol-1 K (2). A maximum of susceptibility is observed at 7 K for 1, and at 15 K for 2 (inset Figure ). These features are characteristic of the occurrence of an antiferromagnetic interaction between the copper(II) ions.
elements.clean_text: Let us discuss first the magnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2. At room temperature, the values of the χM T product are 0.92 cm3 mol-1 K (1) and 0.80 cm3 mol-1 K (2), expected for two isolated spin doublets (Figures  and ). These values remain constant upon cooling until ca. 50 K (for 1), and ca. 80 K (for 2). Below these temperatures, χM T decreases more and more to reach 0.055 (1), and 0.026 cm3 mol-1 K (2). A maximum of susceptibility is observed at 7 K for 1, and at 15 K for 2 (inset Figure ). These features are characteristic of the occurrence of an antiferromagnetic interaction between the copper(II) ions.

elements.content: At first glance, the scheme of the exchange pathways in compound 1 seems to be very complicated. Let us come back to the crystal structure:  the coordination geometry of copper is square pyramidal. Consequently, the unpaired electron of the copper ion is defined by a d x 2 - y 2 type magnetic orbital. Two copper ions can efficiently interact through the two carboxylato bridges, while the out-of-plane exchange pathway, through the pyridyl group, is negligible. It is reasonable to assume that, from the magnetic point of view, the chain is formed by noninteracting dimers. The experimental data can be fitted using the Bleaney−Bowers equation: where J is the exchange coupling parameter, and N, g, β, and k have their usual meaning.
elements.clean_text: At first glance, the scheme of the exchange pathways in compound 1 seems to be very complicated. Let us come back to the crystal structure: the coordination geometry of copper is square pyramidal. Consequently, the unpaired electron of the copper ion is defined by a d x   2  -  y   2  type magnetic orbital. Two copper ions can efficiently interact through the two carboxylato bridges, while the out-of-plane exchange pathway, through the pyridyl group, is negligible. It is reasonable to assume that, from the magnetic point of view, the chain is formed by noninteracting dimers. The experimental data can be fitted using the Bleaney-Bowers equation:    where J is the exchange coupling parameter, and N, g, β, and k have their usual meaning.

elements.content:
Least-squares fit to the data led to the following values:  J = − 7.3 cm-1, g = 2.23.

The value of the exchange parameter can be calculated also with the following relationship:14 where T max is the temperature for which the magnetic susceptibility presents a maximum. For T max = 7 K, we get J = − 7.8 cm-1, a value that is close to the one resulted by fitting all the data. In the case of compound 2, the following values have been obtained:  J = −15.3 cm-1; g = 2.11; ρ = 0.038 (ρ = molar fraction of a paramagnetic impurity). Alternatively, by using the eq 2, and taking into account that the variation of magnetic susceptibility exhibits a maximum at T = 14.5 K (inset Figure ), we obtained J = −16.2 cm-1.
elements.clean_text:
Least-squares fit to the data led to the following values: J = - 7.3 cm-1, g = 2.23. 

The value of the exchange parameter can be calculated also with the following relationship:14     where T max is the temperature for which the magnetic susceptibility presents a maximum. For T max = 7 K, we get J = - 7.8 cm-1, a value that is close to the one resulted by fitting all the data. In the case of compound 2, the following values have been obtained: J = -15.3 cm-1; g = 2.11; ρ = 0.038 (ρ = molar fraction of a paramagnetic impurity). Alternatively, by using the eq 2, and taking into account that the variation of magnetic susceptibility exhibits a maximum at T = 14.5 K (inset Figure ), we obtained J = -16.2 cm-1.

elements.content: The J values obtained for compounds 1 and 2 are smaller than those observed with similar bis(μ-carboxylato-O,O‘) copper(II) complexes. One explanation for this may be the longer Cu···Cu distances in 1 and 2, in comparison with structurally similar dimers.
elements.clean_text: The J values obtained for compounds 1 and 2 are smaller than those observed with similar bis(μ-carboxylato-O,O‘) copper(II) complexes. One explanation for this may be the longer Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances in 1 and 2, in comparison with structurally similar dimers.

elements.content: At room temperature, the value of the χM T for compound 3 is equal to 1.31 cm3 mol-1 K, a value that is as expected for three isolated spin doublets. This value remains constant upon cooling until 30 K, then decreases more and more at low temperatures to reach 1.07 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.9 K (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: At room temperature, the value of the χM T for compound 3 is equal to 1.31 cm3 mol-1 K, a value that is as expected for three isolated spin doublets. This value remains constant upon cooling until 30 K, then decreases more and more at low temperatures to reach 1.07 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.9 K (Figure ).

elements.content: χM T versus T plot for compound 3.
elements.clean_text: 7  χM T versus T plot for compound 3.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 3 can be interpreted by observing that the triads forming the rungs of the stairs do not interact from the magnetic point of view. Indeed, the interaction of the peripheral copper(II) ions from one rung, through the dca bridges, with the copper ions from adjacent rungs, is of axial−axial type, while the magnetic orbitals are of d x 2 - y 2 type. Therefore, the effective exchange pathway is across the nicotinato bridge, which connects the copper ions through their basal positions, whereas the exchange interaction through the dca bridge is much weaker. The energies of the spin states have been obtained by using the following Hamiltonian: The equation giving the temperature dependence of the χM T product is Least-squares fitting to the data leads to the following values:  J = −0.58 cm-1; g = 2.16.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic properties of 3 can be interpreted by observing that the triads forming the rungs of the stairs do not interact from the magnetic point of view. Indeed, the interaction of the peripheral copper(II) ions from one rung, through the dca bridges, with the copper ions from adjacent rungs, is of axial-axial type, while the magnetic orbitals are of d x   2  -  y   2  type. Therefore, the effective exchange pathway is across the nicotinato bridge, which connects the copper ions through their basal positions, whereas the exchange interaction through the dca bridge is much weaker. The energies of the spin  states have been obtained by using the following Hamiltonian:    The equation giving the temperature dependence of the χM T product is    Least-squares fitting to the data leads to the following values: J = -0.58 cm-1; g = 2.16.

elements.content: In all compounds investigated here, the exchange interactions are mediated by the nicotinato ion, with its different bridging functions. As expected, the strongest interaction was found with compounds 1 and 2, since the bridging carboxylato groups bring the copper ions much closer together than in 3.
elements.clean_text: In all compounds investigated here, the exchange interactions are mediated by the nicotinato ion, with its different bridging functions. As expected, the strongest interaction was found with compounds 1 and 2, since the bridging carboxylato groups bring the copper ions much closer together than in 3.

elements.content:
In conclusion, the nicotinato tecton, combined with other coligands, can generate interesting solid-state architectures, with novel topologies of the metallic centers.

cln_elements.content:
Let us discuss first the magnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2. At room temperature, the values of the χM T product are 0.92 cm3 mol-1 K (1) and 0.80 cm3 mol-1 K (2), expected for two isolated spin doublets (Figures and ). These values remain constant upon cooling until ca. 50 K (for 1), and ca. 80 K (for 2). Below these temperatures, χM T decreases more and more to reach 0.055 (1), and 0.026 cm3 mol-1 K (2). A maximum of susceptibility is observed at 7 K for 1, and at 15 K for 2 (inset Figure ). These features are characteristic of the occurrence of an antiferromagnetic interaction between the copper(II) ions.

At room temperature, the value of the χM T for compound 3 is equal to 1.31 cm3 mol-1 K, a value that is as expected for three isolated spin doublets. This value remains constant upon cooling until 30 K, then decreases more and more at low temperatures to reach 1.07 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.9 K (Figure ).

These values remain constant upon cooling until ca. 50 K (for 1), and ca. 80 K (for 2). Below these temperatures, χM T decreases more and more to reach 0.055 (1), and 0.026 cm3 mol-1 K (2). A maximum of susceptibility is observed at 7 K for 1, and at 15 K for 2 (inset Figure ). These features are characteristic of the occurrence of an antiferromagnetic interaction between the copper(II) ions.

metadata.title:
Construction of Tube- and Ladderlike Copper(II)
Coordination Polymers Based on the Nicotinato Tecton
